What are Decision Trees?

A decision tree is a classic tool for mapping choices - a flowchart that starts with a single “root” question and branches out into every possible outcome. For simple, binary choices (“Is the printer on?”), they provide a clear, logical path.

The Unspoken Reason They Fail

For decades, decision trees have been the obvious theoretical solution for capturing complex processes. Their failure in practice has is exponential complexity.

Adding just a few real-world variables - user roles, error states, environmental conditions - causes their branches to explode. Ten yes/no questions can generate over a thousand paths. For anything resembling real operational knowledge, they become monstrous, un-auditable, and utterly unmaintainable.

This isn’t a minor inconvenience; it’s the fundamental bottleneck that has prevented us from properly documenting complex, branching expertise. The ability to truly conquer this complexity would open up a powerful new way to build, maintain, and leverage knowledge in any field.
